title: Denise: Adult Auditory Rehabilitation and the 'Difficult Patient'
chief_complaint: I am having a lot of trouble hearing in group settings and noisy places like restaurants and church. These hearing aids just don't sound right, and the loudness is inconsistent.

problem_summary.onset: Long-standing; first hearing aids in 2001/2004 (historical context), presented to current practice in 2015.
problem_summary.course: Progressive dissatisfaction with amplification; history of multiple hearing aid returns and frequent reprogramming requests ('tweaking').
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Social withdrawal, embarrassment, feeling 'less than', hearing aid casings cracking due to hair products.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Significant participation restrictions in social and family life; HHI score indicates severe handicap.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Desires better hearing but has high cosmetic concerns and reluctance regarding technology costs.

history.present_illness: Patient presented with moderate sloping to profound sensorineural hearing loss. She reported hearing poorly in noise. She was new to wearing hearing aids at this practice but had a history of prior use.
history.otologic_history: Hereditary hair loss mentioned; no specific otologic disease listed.
history.prior_management: Previous hearing aids in 2001 and 2004. Switched from ITE to BTE at this practice.
history.patient_goals: Cosmetic concerns are high (pixie haircut makes aids visible).
history.medical_psych_history: Described as having an 'abrasive interpersonal style' by clinicians.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Bilateral moderate precipitously sloping to profound sensorineural hearing loss. Thresholds drop significantly above 1000 Hz.

tests.name: Articulation Index (AI) Calculation
tests.key_findings: Aided performance is poor due to severity of loss in high frequencies.

history.present_illness: 6-month period of 'tweaking'. Patient requested reprogramming 9 times, returned devices, and complained of casing cracks.
history.prior_management: Fitted with new BTEs. Casing cracked 9 times over 3 years due to hair products.
history.patient_goals: Requests for adjustments were contradictory (more gain vs less gain).

tests.name: Hearing Aid Follow-up
tests.key_findings: Patient made 9 visits between Sept 2015 and March 2016 for reprogramming, returns, and new fittings. Clinicians noted 'indecisiveness' and 'failure to commit'.

history.present_illness: Occurred during the 6th year of treatment. Patient invited to 6-week Group Auditory Rehabilitation (AR) program.
history.patient_goals: Address social and emotional responses to hearing loss.

tests.name: Hearing Handicap Inventory (HHI)
tests.key_findings: Score indicated significant impairment due to hearing loss.

tests.name: Hearing Handicap Inventory (HHI)
tests.key_findings: Significant improvement after 6-week group class. Patient reported understanding the limitations of her hearing aids for the first time.

history.present_illness: 6 months after completing the AR program.
history.prior_management: Benefit from group AR was brief.

tests.name: Hearing Handicap Inventory (HHI)
tests.key_findings: Handicap score increased again, indicating regression.

tests.name: Cochlear Implant Evaluation
tests.key_findings: Audiologists recommended CI consideration. Retrospective analysis suggested she was a candidate as early as 2001/2015 based on audiogram and lack of benefit.

overall_audiologic_summary: Denise presents with a bilateral moderate precipitously sloping to profound sensorineural hearing loss. Despite amplification, her aided Articulation Index is only 0.23, suggesting limited speech audibility (approx. 50% in quiet). She demonstrates significant fluctuation in self-perceived handicap (HHI scores), initially improving with group rehabilitation but regressing shortly after. Her profile is consistent with a candidate for cochlear implantation due to the lack of functional benefit from conventional hearing aids in the high frequencies.
counseling_points: Hearing aids cannot fully restore hearing, especially in the high frequencies where your loss is profound; they are an aid, not a cure.
Frequent 'tweaking' of the hearing aid settings may not provide the clarity you seek because the damage to the inner ear limits what amplification can achieve.
Your feelings of embarrassment and social withdrawal are common, and group rehabilitation can help you realize you are not alone.
Given the limited benefit from hearing aids, a cochlear implant evaluation is strongly recommended to potentially provide better access to speech sounds.
notes_for_actor: Portray a patient who is demanding, indecisive, and frequently dissatisfied ('abrasive interpersonal style').
Express frustration that 'things just don't sound right' despite multiple adjustments.
Show deep concern about the cosmetic appearance of the hearing aids and how they interact with your hair/hairstyle.
Convey a sense of cultural stigma or feeling 'less than' because of the hearing loss.
